> I don't mean to be rude, so please interpret what I'm about to say in
> the nicest possible way. I don't understand why /any/ project would ask
> non-coders (or people who can code, but are not allowed to code on the
> project, like testers) to test any code with JUnit. That misses the
> whole point of what JUnit is for. JUnit is not a testing tool in the
> traditional testing sense. Trying to test code with JUnit /almost
> always/ results in identifying design problems that impede code-level
> testing, and so JUnit is more of a design tool than anything else. If
> all you want to do is automate external (QA-style) tests, then why are
> those tests at the code level? Why aren't they at the product level
> using tools like WinRunner or Silk Performer?


++++many

Are you in a position and do you have the courage to communicate that
> kind of message to your project's manager? or your testing department
> manager? If it helps, you have one of the world's experts on the topic
> giving you the information. :) [The people on this list can vouch for me.]


Vouching for J.B. now.

Cheers
Mark
